items.content_html:
A lesson I learned while teaching my Mom some computer tricks is that I should probablyÂ begin with what a (web) browser is. To do this, I'll start with a somewhat technical definition from Wikipedia, "AÂ web browserÂ (commonly referred to as aÂ browser) is aÂ software applicationÂ for accessing information on theÂ World Wide Web." Great, now lets simplify that a bit. You will likely recognize names such as Chrome, Firefox, Edge or Safari; these are different browsers.Â You open it up andÂ use it to shop on Amazon or Etsy; Duck things on duckduckgo;Â checkout stuff on Pinterest, Reddit or Facebook, etc. You tell the browser what you want to see by typing in an URL, (for example https://google.com) or more likely just type in a search term and off you go!

Hopefully you nowÂ recognize what a browser is but I imagine now you're wondering so what? Who caresÂ what browser I use? For the most part it doesn't make much of a difference. They mayÂ use slightly different styling, orÂ have someÂ special feature you never use, but essentially they all take you to the same place. TheyÂ connect you with websites and hopefully stay out of your way.

I will pick on Chrome for this paragraph because it is mostly developed by the largest internet advertising company on the planet, Google. If I remember correctly,Â Chrome was created to speed up web browsing and improveÂ browser security.Â Around 2010Â Internet Explorer was full of security holes and FirefoxÂ was slow and bloated so the user experience was not particularly good. Also, Google wanted to be sure that the Google search engine remained the default option at least in Chrome since search ads drive a great deal of their revenue; IE or Firefox switching their default search provider at the time could have been very harmful to Google's bottom line.

The green line on the chartÂ below shows the change in Chrome's market share from 2009-2020. Today it controls roughly 65% of the browser market which gives Google a great deal of power in discussions about what standards are introduced and adopted and how they are implemented. Chrome is very slow to adopt the privacy features built-in to their competitor's browsers as they would negatively effect their advertising income. This allows them to better identify and track people in order to serve them more targeted advertisements and make more money.

Chrome is built on top of the open-source Chromium browser. Chrome is essentially Chromium with a Google sweatshirt. Everyone is free to use and change Chromium but that sweatshirt is hiding all of theÂ extra stuff GoogleÂ addsÂ to build the proprietary Chrome. The source code is closed off so no one can see. You can think of Brave as Chromium with a completely different sweatshirt with all of its unique features open to everyone allowing us see, change and help improve it. So you get all of the security and speed benefits without most of the Google enabled tracking and privacy invading aspects of Chrome.Â 

That is the basic building blocks of the Brave browser. The truly revolutionary portion is their long-term goal of replacing the massive user tracking and profiling system that currently powers the internet economy with a privacy preserving advertising system built into the browser. Most internet services such as Gmail, Facebook, Instagram, Tiktok, newspapers, magazines, blogs, etc are funded through advertising. This is why a service like Hulu has a free tier with advertising while Netflix always requires you to pay. The trouble is, this business model incentivizes massive amounts of surveillance across the internet.

"Google controls aboutÂ 62% of mobile browsers,Â 69% of desktop browsers, and the operating systems onÂ 71% of mobile devicesÂ in the world.Â 92% of internet searchesÂ go through Google andÂ 73% of American adultsÂ use YouTube. Google runs code on approximatelyÂ 85% of sites on the WebÂ and insideÂ as many as 94%Â of apps in the Play store. It collects data about usersâ€™ every click, tap, query, and movement from all of those sources and more."Â 

EFF - Google Says It Doesn't 'Sell' Your DataÂ  Â 

Google and Facebook and dozens of other data companies encourage website owners toÂ use their scripts on their websites so that they can track user activity everywhere they go on the internet and target them ads. By default, Brave blocks these trackers and identifying techniques to speed up browsing and protect users from this ridiculousness. Below is a list of tracking scripts blocked on a visit to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel website. Amazon, Facebook, Google and a sea of others are all utilized; drastically slowing down the web page's load time and adding a lot of annoying pop ups and videos to the website.

At this point you might be uneasy but still think, "hey, they need to earn money to pay for their reporting. There aren't that many options for decent, local, investigative journalism and the newspaper industry has been hammered over the years (by Google & Facebook as it turns out.)" This is where Brave stands out from the other browsers. Instead of just blocking ads, Brave users are able to earn money in the form of Basic Attention Tokens (BAT) for allowing Brave toÂ displayÂ ads occasionally. You are able to adjust how frequently theyÂ appear and are not required to enable them; it is an opt-in choice. At this point, the ads display as notifications on your computer or phone and disappear after a few seconds. When ads popup, you earnÂ 70% of the ad revenue while the other 30% goes to BraveÂ providing them with a dedicated funding source. Firefox, the third most used browser, isÂ another open source browser with some ad-blocking but they rely on search engine providers for a large chunk of their annual funding leaving them with an unstable year to year budget and an uncertain future. They face the same problem as newspapers: since less people are using them, they get paid less for the default search engine rights and have less money to compete.

Every monthÂ Brave distributes a user-adjustable percentage of your BAT to theÂ websites you visitÂ based onÂ the amount of time you spent at each site. When the ad is displayed, you earn BAT; no need to click on the ad if you're not interested. The tracking and ad targeting is all done locally on your computer and is never sent anywhere or shared with anyone. ThisÂ allows website owners and content creators to earn money without strong-armingÂ users into giving information to Google and Facebook to sell to ad companies. When you browse Github, Reddit, Twitter or YouTube, the content creators are able to receive BAT instead of just the website operator. This means that Timmy will get BAT for his YouTube video when people watch it, not just YouTube.

Brave seems like a near perfect compromise that benefits users, advertisers and content creators. Users continue to get free content as well as the most private by default browser out there; advertisers can continue to sell their wares; content creators can earn money for endeavors; all without the massive, privacy invading, information dragnet currently in place. I hope to see Brave usage increase and more websites sign on; especially in Milwaukee. Some companies certainly seem to be on board as lately larger companie's ads are showing up. User growth appears to be healthy as well; passing 10 millionÂ last December.

Of the different Milwaukee websites I frequent,Â Urban Milwaukee seems to have the most balanced approach with less tracking for paid members compared to free users. OnMilwaukee.com unfortunately has no paid tier so tracking for everybody! Milwaukee Record uses broadstreetads.com whichÂ usesÂ local advertising which is a plus. All three, regardless of tier, use the ubiquitous Google Analytics found on a large swath of the internet. Google Analytics monitors mouse movements, clicks, time spent on pages and much more; sending it all back to Google servers. The City of Milwaukee and Milwaukee County websites both have Google mixed in as well. Milwaukee County Blog use a locally hosted instance of MatomoÂ so nobody gets any information butÂ MCB and it is setup with some anonymizing settings enabled since I'm only interested in the number of visitors and if they come back (so far nobody but botsÂ ğŸ˜¥.)

Even if Brave doesn't sound like your cup of tea, I highly encourage people to install uBO-Scope (Firefox users / Brave & Chrome users) so you can see all of the different companies tracking your every move online. If seeing all of the tracking doesn't make Brave or an ad blocker like uBlock Origin more appealing to you then so be it.

items.content_html:
A recent press release fromÂ The Hop offers details about the 8.5 foot â€œSmart Kiosksâ€Â being introduced to Milwaukeeâ€™s streetcar stopsÂ beginning inÂ May. Cities around the world have been forming relationships with companies such as Smart City Media to create new sources of income for municipalities as well as bridge the gap between online advertising and peopleâ€™s habits in the physical world.

The idea normally revolves around using cameras, sensors and various other tracking techniques to connect people's online advertising profilesÂ to their actions in the physical world while offering a somewhat useful tool in return at no cost to the municipality. Did Sam go to the store and buy that home mushroom farm we advertised on Instagram?

These agreementsÂ often create concerns as aÂ result of privacy and security considerations being an afterthought of companies and municipalities. When companies that specialize in advertising offer something for free, there is a trade offÂ that often comes at the expense of an individual's privacy. When a budget strapped city such as Milwaukee is offered up to $500,000 annually at no expense, they tend not toÂ focusÂ on the details.

Should a casual walk down the street require surveillance by the Milwaukee Police Department? Do these kiosks use beacons or WiFi-tracking techniques to track where people are going regardless of whether they connected to the WiFi and agreed to the terms? Answers to the questions below could help address these sorts of concerns.

  1. What and where is the privacy policy for these devices?
  2. What types of data are collected?
  3. How and why is it collected?
  4. How is the collected data anonymized?
  5. Is tracking limited to users that connect to the WiFi?
  6. Is the video and audio recording 24/7 or activated by the emergency feature?
  7. Who owns the video and audio data? Where and howÂ is it stored? What is the retention policy? How will MPD use the video and audio feeds?
  8. What restrictions are in place onÂ Smart City Media's usage and/or sale of collected data?
  9. What oversight isÂ there to assure Smart City Media is following the termsÂ of the contract in relation to data use, privacy and retention policies?
  10. How frequently are these devices' software and OS updated?
  11. Who owns the streetcar tracking and arrival time data?

Smart City MediaÂ appears to be an honest company that providesÂ useful productsÂ and provides a fair bargainÂ with municipalities around the country. However, more information needs to be provided. The video surveillance aspect is particularlyÂ troubling asÂ law enforcement should be limited to monitoring individuals suspected of crimes after getting a warrant; not broad, indiscriminate monitoring of large swaths of the city. As Bruce Schneier states in his book Secrets and Lies,Â "it is poor civic hygiene to install technologies that could someday facilitate a police state."

Several other cities reversed course on the â€œsmart kiosksâ€ idea. In 2017, Seattleâ€™s mayor rejected an initial proposal from Intersection. Her communications director stated,

â€œMayor Durkan had significant concerns with both the privacy and data policies â€” specifically what data was collected, how it was stored, what tracking was possible, and how ads were targeted.â€

New York City had privacy issues exposed with their smart payphone kiosksÂ installed throughout the city. â€œLinkNYC kiosks, at no cost to the city, would provide free internet coverage to anyone walking by.â€ The company working with NYC in this case also accidentally uploaded some testing source-code to Github,

â€œ...the â€œLinkNYC Mobile Observationâ€ code collects the userâ€™s longitude and latitude, as well as the userâ€™s browser type, operating system, device type, device identifiers, and full URL clickstreams (including date and time) and aggregates this information into a database. In Meyersâ€™s view, this code â€” along with the functions of the â€œRxLocationâ€ codebase â€” suggests that the company is interested in tracking the locations of Wi-Fi users in real time. If such code were run on a mobile app or kiosk, he said, the company would be able to make advertisements available in real time based on where and who someone was, and that this would constitute a potential violation of the companyâ€™s privacy policy. In 2016, LinkNYCâ€™s privacy policy made it clear that it did not collect information about usersâ€™ precise locations. â€œHowever,â€ it states, â€œwe know where we provide WiFi services, so when you use the services we can determine your general location.â€

Â To reiterate, Smart City Media does not have a record of malfeasance that is readily discoverable through a quick duckduckgo search. That being said, it will benefit residents, visitors and ourÂ representatives to slow down, get clear answers to the above questions, verify that the proper safeguards are in place and that excessively intrusive technologies will not be introduced into our daily lives. Advertisements, like police, are necessary andÂ beneficialÂ to society but they should not beÂ profilingÂ our everyÂ click and movement (unless we have done something to trulyÂ justify it ğŸ˜‰.)
